title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol, as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the Secretary of the Air Force. The Secretary appoints a National Board of Directors composed of Air Force general officers and senior civilian employees. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol includes general officers of the Air Force, senior civilian employees, and appointed members from the volunteer membership. The chairman is the senior active duty Air Force officer. The Board appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. These appointees report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General appointed under paragraph (1) report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the National Board of Directors. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The appointment or assignment of members of the armed forces or civilian employees is not restricted by any law prohibiting their participation in non-Federal entity management. Officers or enlisted members serving in Civil Air Patrol management positions do not receive additional compensation beyond their regular military pay. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors can utilize Civil Air Patrol employees and volunteers as needed to run the organization and support the Air Force's noncombat missions. Members and employees of the Civil Air Patrol are not considered federal employees and are exempt from federal employment laws, including compensation, benefits, and ethics regulations. The Civil Air Patrol is subject to federal regulations regarding funds management and standards of conduct, but the Secretary of the Air Force can still set behavior standards for its members and employees. The organization's powers, including adopting a constitution, are subject to the Secretary's approval and any related policies or regulations. The Civil Air Patrol's constitution, bylaws, and regulations require approval from the Secretary of the Air Force. The organization's powers are subject to federal regulations and any policies set by the Secretary. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Civil Air Patrol's constitution, bylaws, and regulations require approval from the Secretary of the Air Force for management. Assistance may be provided by other agencies.
